name: places/ChIJ4b0axELzwokRBqENgsxMHv0
formattedAddress: 238-224 Dyckman St, New York, NY 10034, USA
adrFormatAddress: 238-224 Dyckman St, New York, NY 10034, USA

originalText.text: I’ve been in this neighborhood all my life so I remember when this area was completely desolate. Now you can enjoy. Delicious meal in one of the restaurants that line this area. You can go early in the day when it’s family friendly or at night for drinks and dancing. The plaza is closed to cars so you can sit there and people watch or have a relaxing time with friends. If you pass early in the morning you can see celebrities and journalists filming there.

originalText.text:
Historically this residential block lined with bars and restaurants was a source of noise issues (with plenty of 311 data and news articles to back it up), but this has been managed much better in recent years.  It's a great space physically, recently renovated, and a nice break from busy Broadway.

It was a good idea to pedestrianize the space and add the important bike lane connector to allow smooth greenway-to-greenway traffic.

Despite being made a permanent plaza in 2021, this is still a work in progress that is technically still operating as an Open Restaurants on Open Streets rather than as a true public plaza.  (Public plazas do not currently allow use of the space by private restaurants, for example, and appear on the DOT list of public plazas, which as of August 2022 this does not.)   The rules are apparently still being written, so stay tuned.  For now, it is primarily a very attractive outdoor dining plaza with some intermittent programming at times.

originalText.text:
If I could give zero stars I would. This Plaza (December 9, 2022) is in terrible shape.

The first, most timely problem? The ENORMOUS Christmas tree in an inappropriate place at the eastern point of the Lt. William Tighe triangle.  Is the sidewalk of that triangle even part of the Quisqueya Plaza?  Why is the tree not on Dyckman Street between Broadway and Seaman Avenues...a space that is more plentiful and is definitely part of the Plaza.  Not only is it in a tight spot (impeding pedestrian passage), but it 95% blocks the view of the RING Garden Christmas tree and Menorah. It is also aesthetically unappealing to put it mildly.

Secondly, the tree pit at the western end has a smashed pumpkin on it. That same tree pit was re-done months ago in such a way as to curtail the growth and health of the tree.  Did DOT ask any arborists before wily-nily putting concrete inches from the trunk?

Thirdly, there is at least one dead tree (evergreen) in one of the several moveable wooden planters.

There is more, but I will stop here and submit these same comments to DOT and Community Board 12...the entities "in charge" of the Plaza.  EDIT:  It seems the Plaza is run by the restaurants?..as described on this website?  To be continued!

originalText.text: Total disaster zone for the immediate residents.  All night noise from restaurants and street parties.  Many residents have left because of the complete takeover of PUBLIC land.  This has turned in a RESTAURANT ONLY OPEN PLAZA.  IT IS PRIVATE USAGE ONLY.
